awd_titl_txt: Molecular Scale Study of Peptide Interaction with Metal Oxide Nanoparticles
awd_abstract_narration:
The Environmental Chemical Sciences (ECS) program of the Division of Chemistry will support the research program of Profs. Joel Pedersen and Robert Hamers of University of Wisconsin, Madison. Profs. Pedersen and Hamers and their students will investigate the interaction of well-defined peptides with metal oxide nanoparticles as a first step toward a deeper understanding of how nanoparticles interact with proteins. Titanium dioxide and aluminum oxide will be used as model systems for investigation. The specific aims of the study are: (i) employ discovery tools (phage-display methods) to identify binding motifs in short peptide sequences (heptapeptides) that lead to high affinity for nanoparticles of environmental relevance; (ii) investigate the thermodynamics and kinetics of peptide binding to TiO2 and Al2O3 nanoparticles, using both binding sequences identified via phage-display methods and simpler combinations of amino acids in tetrapeptides to elucidate binding rules; and (iii) identify the peptide functional groups that interact with the nanoparticles and understand the nature of peptide-surface bonds by combining experimental with computational methods. 

The outcome of this research will be a fundamental understanding of the molecular level interactions that control the interactions of peptides with metal oxide nanoparticles. Knowledge of how factors such as peptide sequence, nanoparticle composition and structure, and solution composition affect peptide-nanoparticle interactions will provide insights into the physical and chemical processes that ultimately control the environmental safety and health impacts of nanomaterials. The project will provide outstanding educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students desiring to understand the interface between nanomaterials and biological systems.

por.por_cntn:
The responsible development of nanotechnology requires a fundamental molecular understanding of nanoparticle interactions with biomolecules. The aim of this work was to develop a molecular level understanding of how proteins interact with nanoparticles of titanium dioxide nanoparticles, a nanomaterial with much commercial and industrial importance. We  focused on general rules that govern the interaction of peptide sequences with specific materials. We expect that the methodology of this work, which differed from past attempts to determine inorganic nanomaterials binding peptides, will establish a precedent for how to understand and predict protein-particle interactions. We used engineered viruses to identify binding sites in short peptide sequences that lead to high affinity to nanoscale titanium oxide. Our studies yielded information about how peptide sequence affects peptide-nanoparticle interactions. One peptide that was particularly strongly selected for and contained binding sites specific for nanoscale titanium dioxide was selected for detailed study. We used both experimental and computational approaches to identify the binding site in this peptide and to gain insight into the molecular scale mechanism by which this peptide interacts with the titanium surface. The computational studies led us to make several advances. We developed a novel sampling methodology and showed that a reliable description of the binding process requires a consideration of how the structure of water molecules around the binding site changes. Overall, we view our study as an initial step toward a deeper understanding of protein interaction with nanoparticles, a process with wide-ranging technological and environmental health implications and ultimately governing nanoparticle in interactions with biological systems.

 

 The project impacted the graduate studies of one M.S. and four Ph.D. students. Undergraduate and middle school students were included in the research enterprise. The project also led to the development of a laboratory module in an undergraduate chemistry course.
